Title: Integral $\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \arctan(e^x) \arctan(e^{-x})dx=\frac{7}{4}\zeta(3)$
Content: How to prove that $$\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \arctan(e^x) \arctan(e^{-x})\rm dx=\frac{7}{4}\zeta(3)?$$ This integral appeared while attempting to solve an unanswered question, namely: Closed form of :$ \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\arctan\left(e^{-x^2 \text{erf}(x)}\right)\,\arctan\left(e^{x^2\text{erf(x)}}\right)\,dx $ I happened to find that $$\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \arctan(e^x) ~\arctan(e^{-x})~dx=\frac{7}{4}\zeta(3).$$ How can you work out the answer on the right by hand? I guess that there could be multiple approaches to solve this one.
AcceptedAnswer: $$\int_{-\infty}^\infty \arctan(e^x)\arctan(e^{-x})dx\overset{e^{x}=t}=\int_0^\infty \frac{\arctan t \arctan(1/t)}{t}dt$$ $$\overset{t=\tan x}=\int_0^\frac{\pi}{2} \frac{x(\pi/2-x)}{\sin x\cos x}dx \overset{2x=t}=\frac14 \int_0^{\pi}\frac{t(\pi-t)}{\sin t}dt\overset{t=\pi x}=\frac{\pi^3}4 \int_0^1 \frac{x-x^2}{\sin(\pi x)}dx$$ Combinging with this post gives us the desired result: $$\boxed{\int_{-\infty}^\infty \arctan(e^x)\arctan(e^{-x})dx=\frac{7\zeta(3)}{4}}$$
